subject: RE: [junit] black box or white box?
msgSnippet: ... They can be made solid enough.  I myself also do iterative development.  I work toward the usage of the component before I focus on 100% functionality. ...
messageBody:
> From: Johannes Link [mailto:john.link@...]
>
> Sometimes the (public) contract cannot be made sufficiently
> strong beforehand. Especially when the objects and interfaces
> are in the midst of evolving.

They can be made solid enough. I myself also do iterative
development. I work toward the usage of the component before
I focus on 100% functionality.

>
> Well, maybe the difference of our views lies in the fact that
> I personally do as much test-driven, i.e. test-first
> development as possible where the design and thus the
> contracts come slowly into being (and often disappear
> quickly). Martin Fowler calls that evolutionary design and I
> guess that I often don't take the time to get the contracts
> straight and tight enough.

That is a slight difference in approach. I look at the interface
first, then the testing, and finally the implementation. I tend
to look at my system somewhat like a play. Each component has
a "role" to play in the system. Each role interacts with other
roles in a predefined manner (aka script or contract). I also
tend to have several small components or interfaces, and have
them delegate to other components as need be. That makes it
easier to understand/design.

To me, the interface is the criteria I have for making the tests.
Now, until the component is ready, the interface is marked as
a developmental interface. That means that the test and the
interface can change. I work torwards stablizing the interface
ASAP. I also use the Java "interface" keyword to define my
interfaces.

interface Store
{
void store(String key, Object val);
Object retrieve(String key);
void remove(String key);
}

That interface is enough to know how to use the object store.
If I need a guarantee that an object store keeps the object
references persistently, I use another interface to represent
that additional contract:

interface PersistentStore extends Store {}

That way I have the option of using a memory bound storage,
a cache like storage, or a more permanent storage.

If I need the guarantee of permanance, I use a component that
implements the PersistentStore interface.

It just helps me get there quicker.


> Since your examples are taken from Excalibur I suppose that
> you, Berin, are following a component-oriented and more
> "design-up-front" development strategy. It could be that this
> difference results in different testing strategies as well.
>

Yes I am. The two examples I gave though are not components
in the classic sense. They are utility classes that other
components can use.

There are different needs with component testing than with
regular class testing. I believe I posted a very quick
summary of the difference between components and objects
in another post to the list.
